comments.body: Please avoid Scala-style for loops for now and use while loops instead. We're currently not quite there optimisation-wise to remove the overhead they have.

comments.body: This one should be `override def toString(): String = this.asInstanaceOf[_String]`. Given that both `String` and `_String` are the same types at NIR-level, this will be a no-op.
Please avoid higher-level Scala constructs like `Try` for now as they are not guaranteed to be optimised away at the moment.

comments.body: `ConsolePrintStream` should be an inner class, not in the companion. Otherwise it will have binary-incompatible name in the compiled code.
The same feedback as for `ConsolePrintStream` applies here.

comments.body:
I'm skeptical about this `lastCharset` business. It looks like premature optimization to me, and it's not even clear that it's an optimization. An application sensibly working always with `Charset`s (rather than charset names) would just pay the cost of storing this global field every time for nothing.

Besides, if there's anywhere this caching should be done, it should be in `Charset.forName`, not in every single method that takes a charset name as parameter.

I recommend commenting that out if it is not correctly implemented, so that the linker can report linking errors, rather than silently producing an incorrect program.

comments.body: it ignores the locale for now?

Yes, `Locale` is not used for now. In Harmony 6.0 there was a special case for Turkish. The newer Harmony https://github.com/apache/harmony/blob/java6/classlib/modules/luni/src/main/java/java/lang/String.java#L1629-L1642 defers to icu4j `UCharacter` which defers to `UCaseProps` which has a couple of special cases for Turkish and Lithuanian but I think this should get us pretty close. Overall, this stuff is really complex especially icu4j which is a complete Unicode implementation.

Also, we are waiting for `System.getProperties: Properties` so that we can create a `Locale` object based on `LANG` in the `env`. See #577.
I think it's acceptable to ignore it for now as long as there is an issue open. We'll improve it later on.

This is uselessly inefficient for such a core class. We should avoid the double reversal. Here is another oneliner that doesn't reverse twice:
```scala
this.substring(0, this.lastIndexWhere(!_.isWhitespace) + 1)
```

`new _String` is redundant and will create another copy of the string:
```suggestion
    value.dropWhile(_.isWhitespace)
```

`forall` on an empty sequence always returns `true` (since it is the neutral operation of `&&`:
```suggestion
    value.forall(_.isWhitespace)
```

```suggestion
    (this: String) * count
```

If using `split`, you can take advantage of the fact that it accepts a regex:
```scala
this.split("\r\n?|\n")
```
